content:
✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Quickly solvable in a compact manner if one knows their language (at least in the most common ones) - or is able to quickly look it up. Both are valuable skills to have or to learn, so I think this fits well. Description is also clear, approved!

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: la solution proposée fais un peu peur...
mais le problème est faisable en 3,4 ligne aussi.

import datetime
epoch = datetime.datetime.fromtimestamp(int(input()))
time = str(epoch).split(" ")[1]
print(epoch.strftime("%d/%m/%Y"))
print(time)

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: the nature of the puzzle lets it be solved using built in functions to create short code (which is one of the modes this is listed for). for clash of code, a lightweight puzzle like this makes sense.

using a function from a module in python really helped to streamline the function, then the only real challenge is doing formating on the string depending on the language. and thats not even a challenge. A nice and simple puzzle that seems complex works well for the time-limited clash of code.
Maybe you could add a little about what leap years are and how they will impact the program. Reminding the first leap year since 1970 could be a good idea too

one of the simplest challenges I saw. But not really true. You forgot to take leap seconds in account

leap seconds : https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Leap_second
french version : https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seconde_intercalaire

bash answer, less than 1 minute

date -d @`cat` +'%d/%m/%Y
%H:%M:%S'
I don't think the length of the solution is suitable for a CoC challenge.
Couldn't people just use built in language features to achieve this in 1-2 lines of code?

Yep, C for example has some features that can help a lot but you still have to format the output. 
There are different ways to solve this puzzle : knowing your programming language and use the built-in function or build an algorithm ¯\_(ツ)_/¯

I actually coded mine in less than 5 minutes. I had already dealt with the same kind of problem so it was easier but I think it's really possible in less than 15 minutes. Plus, as mentioned in other comments, there are a lot of built-in features that can be really helpful. These problems are the ones challenging you to discover your favorite language's hidden features (:

un peu plus long en python...

import datetime
epoch = datetime.datetime.fromtimestamp(int(input()))
time = str(epoch).split(" ")[1]
print(epoch.strftime("%d/%m/%Y"))
print(time)
Well I was just thinking that the example you provided insinuated you expected people to do it all manually.
